parts: Devise a procedure by which I can construct a 2 by 2 matrix A with real entries such that (A^*)(A) has distinct eigenvalues which are perfect squares.

**Crafting a matrix**

I'm gathering a 2x2 real matrix \(A\) with distinct singular values that are perfect squares, aiming for a symmetric positive semidefinite matrix \(A^T A\) with those squares as eigenvalues.

First, note that for a real \(2\times 2\) matrix \(A\), the matrix \(A^* A\) (which, over the reals, is just \(A^T A\)) is symmetric and positive semidefinite. Its eigenvalues coincide with the squares of the singular values of \(A\). So if you want \(A^T A\) to have two *distinct* perfect-square eigenvalues, you want \(A\) to have two distinct *integer* singular values. 

The easiest construction therefore is:

1. **Pick distinct positive integers** \(p\) and \(q\). They will be the singular values of \(A\).  
2. **Form the diagonal matrix** \(S = \begin{pmatrix} p & 0 \\ 0 & q \end{pmatrix}.\)  
3. **Choose any pair of orthogonal matrices** \(U,V\in O(2)\). (Real orthogonal \(2\times 2\) matrices have the form \(\begin{pmatrix} \cos\theta & -\sin\theta \\ \sin\theta & \cos\theta \end{pmatrix}\).)  
4. **Construct \(A\)** by setting
   \[
   A \;=\; U\,S\,V^T.
   \]
   This ensures \(A\) has singular values \(p\) and \(q\).  

Now,
\[
A^T A \;=\;(U S V^T)^T (U S V^T)
        \;=\; V S^T U^T U S V^T
        \;=\; V S^T S \,V^T
        \;=\; V \begin{pmatrix} p^2 & 0 \\ 0 & q^2 \end{pmatrix} V^T.
\]
Because \(p\neq q\), the eigenvalues are the distinct numbers \(p^2\) and \(q^2\).  By construction, these are perfect squares.  

### A simple explicit example
Take \(p=2\) and \(q=3\), and let \(U = I\) and \(V = I\). Then
\[
A \;=\; S \;=\; \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 0 \\ 0 & 3 \end{pmatrix}
\]
and
\[
A^T A \;=\; \begin{pmatrix} 4 & 0 \\ 0 & 9 \end{pmatrix},
\]
whose eigenvalues are clearly 4 and 9—distinct perfect squares.  

In short, to make \(A^T A\) have distinct, perfect-square eigenvalues, simply pick any two distinct positive integers as the singular values of \(A\). This is enough to guarantee \(A^T A\) will have those distinct integer squares as its eigenvalues.
Can a more general procedure be created so that I can generate matrices A that are non-diagonal?

To create non-diagonal 2x2 matrices A with distinct perfect square eigenvalues, choose distinct positive integers p and q as singular values. Define orthogonal matrices U and V with rotation angles α and β, then form A = U S V^T.

Certainly! The most general approach uses the **singular value decomposition (SVD)** idea, but in a simple 2×2 setting. We already know that for a 2×2 real matrix \(A\), the matrix \(A^T A\) has eigenvalues equal to the squares of the singular values of \(A\). Therefore, to ensure \(A^T A\) has distinct perfect-square eigenvalues, we want \(A\) to have two distinct positive integer singular values (say \(p\neq q\), both integers).

---

## General Procedure

1. **Choose two distinct positive integers** \(p\) and \(q\). These will be your singular values.

2. **Form the diagonal matrix**
   \[
   S \;=\; \begin{pmatrix} p & 0\\[6pt] 0 & q \end{pmatrix}.
   \]

3. **Choose any two real 2×2 orthogonal matrices** \(U\) and \(V\).  
   - A real orthogonal matrix \(Q\) in 2D has the form  
     \[
       Q(\theta) \;=\; \begin{pmatrix}
         \cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\
         \sin \theta & \cos \theta
       \end{pmatrix}
     \]
     (this is a rotation), or a rotation combined with a reflection, etc. In general, any matrix \(Q\) satisfying \(Q^T Q = I\) is orthogonal. 
   - You can parametrize \(U\) by some angle \(\alpha\) and \(V\) by another angle \(\beta\). For instance, you might set
     \[
       U \;=\; \begin{pmatrix}
         \cos \alpha & -\sin \alpha\\[4pt]
         \sin \alpha & \cos \alpha
       \end{pmatrix},
       \quad
       V \;=\; \begin{pmatrix}
         \cos \beta & -\sin \beta\\[4pt]
         \sin \beta & \cos \beta
       \end{pmatrix}.
     \]

4. **Construct \(A\)** by taking
   \[
   A \;=\; U \, S \, V^T.
   \]
   In other words,
   \[
     A \;=\; 
       \begin{pmatrix}
         \cos \alpha & -\sin \alpha\\[2pt]
         \sin \alpha &  \cos \alpha
       \end{pmatrix}
       \begin{pmatrix} p & 0\\[2pt] 0 & q \end{pmatrix}
       \begin{pmatrix}
         \cos \beta & \sin \beta\\[2pt]
        -\sin \beta & \cos \beta
       \end{pmatrix}.
   \]
   (Note that \(V^T\) just flips the sign on \(\beta\) if \(V\) is a pure rotation; for more general orthogonal \(V\), you still get an orthogonal factor \(V^T\).)

### Why This Works

- **Distinct perfect-square eigenvalues**:  
  Because the singular values of \(A\) are \(p\) and \(q\), the eigenvalues of \(A^T A\) are \(p^2\) and \(q^2\). Since \(p\neq q\), these eigenvalues are distinct.  
- **Non-diagonal \(A\)**:  
  As soon as either \(U\) or \(V\) (or both) is not the identity matrix, the resulting product \(U S V^T\) is generally a full (non-diagonal) 2×2 matrix. Indeed, varying \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\) will produce infinitely many such matrices \(A\).  

---

## Explicit Non-Diagonal Example

- Pick \(p = 2\) and \(q = 3\).  
- Let \(U = R(\alpha)\) and \(V = R(\beta)\) with \(\alpha = 30^\circ\) and \(\beta = 45^\circ\).  

Then
\[
U \;=\; \begin{pmatrix}
  \cos 30^\circ & -\sin 30^\circ \\
  \sin 30^\circ &  \cos 30^\circ
\end{pmatrix}
\;=\;
\begin{pmatrix}
  \sqrt{3}/2 & -1/2 \\
  1/2        & \sqrt{3}/2
\end{pmatrix},
\]
\[
V \;=\; \begin{pmatrix}
  \cos 45^\circ & -\sin 45^\circ \\
  \sin 45^\circ &  \cos 45^\circ
\end{pmatrix}
\;=\;
\begin{pmatrix}
  \tfrac{\sqrt{2}}{2} & -\tfrac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \\
  \tfrac{\sqrt{2}}{2} & \tfrac{\sqrt{2}}{2}
\end{pmatrix},
\]
\[
S \;=\;
\begin{pmatrix}
  2 & 0 \\
  0 & 3
\end{pmatrix}.
\]
Then
\[
A \;=\; U S V^T
\]
will be a real 2×2 matrix, generally non-diagonal, with
\[
A^T A = V\, S^T S\,V^T 
= V \begin{pmatrix} 4 & 0 \\ 0 & 9 \end{pmatrix} V^T.
\]
The eigenvalues of this matrix are 4 and 9, as desired.

Hence, this **general SVD-based construction** allows you to produce infinitely many real 2×2 matrices \(A\)—including those that are not diagonal—such that \(A^T A\) has distinct, perfect-square eigenvalues.
